Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I stared at the lines of code on my screen, the cursor blinking impatiently. The team’s messages kept popping up—everyone was waiting for my module, the core piece that would let the rest of the build move forward. I could feel the pressure mounting, the expectation that I, as the lead engineer, would deliver a solution quickly and flawlessly. But as the clock ticked past noon, I felt another pull inside me. It was time for my daily puja, the ritual that grounds me, connects me to something deeper. Lately, I’d been whispering a short mantra under my breath, hoping it would be enough, but guilt gnawed at me for not performing the full ritual. My family expected me to uphold our traditions, and I expected it of myself too. Yet, the thought of stepping away from my desk, even for a few minutes, seemed impossible. The team needed me. My faith needed me. I sat frozen, torn between the demands of my work and the quiet call of my beliefs, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from either side.
